Attapulgus Operations

141 Engelhard Rd

Attapulgus, GA 39815



RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.0  Chemical Accident Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

BASF Corporation Attapulgus Operations (BASF) facility management is committed to the successful  implementation of the requirements of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) in accordance with the EPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68. BASF's objective is to minimize the risk of a release of anhydrous ammonia (ammonia) and, if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to BASF's employees, the public, and the  environment.  BASF adheres to general good operating practices, providing appropriate training to all employees, complying with pertinent codes and regulations, and proactively planning and coordinating emergency response activities with BASF's local emergency response providers.  BASF's management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this policy.



2.0  Facility Description

BASF manufactures petroleum catalysts, including fluid cracking and moving bed catalysts, for sale to oil refineries. As part of this process, BASF uses anhydrous ammonia for pH control in various applications in sufficient quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions. Ammonia is delivered to the facility via tank truck.  The Attapulgus Site has one 12,000-gal ammonia storage tank containing up to about 52,000 lbs. of ammonia.



3.0  General Chemical Accident Prevention Program and Ammonia-Specific Prevention Steps

BASF Attapulgus is governed by a set of OSHA and EPA (and corresponding Georgia) regulations that requiring measures to prevent a release of hazardous materials.  These rules also require the facility to minimize the consequences of an accidental release to the facility's employees, the public, and the environment. Some of these OSHA and EPA regulations include:



29 CFR Part 1910.120, 1910.38, 1910.165

OSHA, Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response, Employee Emergency Plans and Fire Prevention Plans, and Employee Alarm Systems

40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions

40 CFR Part 110, Discharge of Oil

40 CFR Part 112, Oil Pollution Prevention

40 CFR Part 117, Determination of Reportable Quantities for Hazardous Substances

40 CFR Part 122, EPA-Administered Permit Programs: National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System

40 CFR Part 262, Standards Applicable to Generators of Hazardous Waste

40 CFR Part 302, Designation, Notification, and Reportable Quantities

40 CFR Part 355, Emergency Planning and Notification



BASF has implemented an ammonia-specific accident prevention program in conformance with the provisions of 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, and Georgia's Rules of Safety Fire Commissioner Chapter 120-3-12, Rules and Regulations for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia. Key concepts of this program include periodic Process Hazard Analyses (PHA), operations/maintenance procedures and training, Management of Change, Pre-Startup Review, periodic compliance audits and incident investigations, and employee participation in site safety processes.



3.1.  Process Hazard Analyses

A team of BASF employees conducts a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) on the ammonia system using current Process Safety Information. The PHA is designed to proactively identify and address any system weaknesses in order to prevent accidental ammonia releases. Items identified are documented and appropriate work orders submitted.  Procedures are in place to maintain the PHA consistent with the current ammonia process and to update and revalidate it at least every five years.



3.2.  Procedures and Training

It is the Attapulgus Site's policy to ensure that its employees are provided clear instructions for safely conducting all work-related activities. The ammonia system has a set of related standard operating procedures (SOPs)

and safe work practices. Employees operating the ammonia system receive SOP training and safe work practices to ensure that they have the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties. It is also the site's policy to inspect, test, and maintain its process equipment in a manner consistent with applicable manufacturer's recommendations and  recognized good engineering practices. BASF has ammonia-related maintenance procedures addressing preventative maintenance and repairs, hot work permits, etc. designed to prevent accidental ammonia releases. Maintenance mechanics and technicians receive appropriate training in these procedures to ensure that they have the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties. In addition, the Attapulgus Site has a contractor program to ensure that all outside contractors are familiar with and meet or exceed all site safety standards and practices.



3.3.  Management of Change and Pre-Startup Review Processes

BASF has Management of Change (MOC) and Pre- Startup Review processes in place to ensure that safety and health considerations and procedural and training requirements are addressed in conjunction with any change being implemented.  The Attapulgus site utilizes a company wide database that tracks MOC notifications and assignments to individuals and teams to properly and timely implement any required changes to the operations.



3.4.  Compliance Audits and Incident Investigations

BASF conducts routine audits of its ammonia accident prevention program to ensure the program's effectiveness and identify continuous improvement opportunities. In the event an ammonia release occurs or a near miss is identified, BASF has an Incident Investigation and an Emergency Response Team trained to quickly identify root causes and appropriate actions to prevent future releases. These investigations are reviewed to further manage the safety of BASF's manufacturing processes.



3.5.  Employee Participation

An

ongoing objective in support of an incident free facility is to include all employees in all facets of safety programs and any changes. Participation in site safety efforts is required and monitored by the training coordinator.  Employees participate in various safety processes such as Workplace Inspections, Behavioral Safety Observations, Job Safety Analyses, Root Cause Analyses, Process Hazard Analysis, etc.



4.0  Five Year Accident History

BASF Attapulgus facility has had no releases of ammonia that have affected onsite personnel, the public, or the environment in the past five years.  An internal BASF database is reviewed as well as all environmental records that require notification to verify the release history.



5.0  Emergency Response Program

BASF Attapulgus has an onsite emergency response capable of responding to an ammonia release emergency. BASF trained personnel serve as first responders and will contact offsite emergency responders, Decatur County Emergency Management Agency and Decatur County Fire Department, for assistance in the event of an ammonia release emergency.  In the event of a non-emergency ammonia release, BASF employees trained in the safe operation of the ammonia system will close automatic and manual shutoff valves to terminate the flow of ammonia.  BASF and Decatur County officials meet on an annual schedule to review the emergency response program and provide each group with updates of any nature that may affect the response team. 



6.0  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

BASF has made the following improvements to the safety of its ammonia system (past 5 years):

?    Installed additional ammonia monitors within the facility for detection of possible leaks



Planned improvements include:

?    Review of possible alternative chemical processes to reduce use of anhydrous ammonia
